newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: ASIAN EXOTICS - Regionals dampened by dollar bulls.
newsitem.headline: ASIAN EXOTICS - Regionals dampened by dollar bulls.

text.p: * Baht eased on strong commercial demand for the dollar
* Ringgit pressured but supported by fears of Bank Negara's presence to cap dollar rise at 2.5250
* Rupiah softens after government's deregulation package did not contain any band widening
* Singapore dollar stays weak on U.S. dollar demand.
* Taiwan dollar weak but off lows on central bank intervention
* Peso takes breather, seen at desired range. No signs of central bank intervention
Bulls dominated the U.S. dollar on Tuesday, pressuring most Asian currencies and prompting efforts by some central banks to shore their currencies.
Almost a week since the Thai government announced a managed float exchange rate system, the baht remained weak against the dollar amid persistent commercial demand for the dollar.
Local importers and foreign loan borrowers who needed the the dollar for payment on imported goods and loan repayments were among dollar buyers, dealers said.
The baht was trading at 29.130/230 against the greenback compared to 28.90/29.00 on late Monday.
The Bank of Thailand set its reference rate at 28.922 to the dollar against 28.578 on Monday.
In the offshore market, the baht traded at 28.700/900 against 28.50/80 on Monday.
Dollar buying by hedge funds pressured the ringgit but upside on the dollar was capped by fears of Bank Negara's presence at 2.5250 ringgit to the dollar.
"There has been a lot of buying of dollar by hedge funds but Negara is waiting at the 2.5250 level. It will be very tight today, maybe 2.5240/50," said a delaer with a Eruopean bank in Singapore.
At 0400 GMT, the ringgit was trading at 2.5240/50 to the dollar.

Indonesian rupiah softened against the dollar. Singapore operators were buying dollars after Indonesia's economic deregulation package did not contain the widely-speculated widening of the dollar-rupiah band, removing some of the arguments for going short in dollars.
"There is no fresh factor to trade on. The package contains nothing about the band," the dealer said, adding that players were covering part of their short dollar positions.
Spot rupiah was at 2,433.0/33.5 at 0225 GMT, compared with an opening of 2,431.00/31.75. Tomorrow and today rupiah was at 2,432.75/33.10 and 2,432.25/32.75, respectively.
Analysts said sentiment remained positive because the deregulation package could stimulate the stock market which had posted several record highs in the past few days.
A dealer in Singapore said overall trading was quiet, with a biddish tone on the dollar against the baht seen causing a slight weakening of the rupiah.
"It's a quiet day. In the swap market, rates are trapped in a narrow range because of a two-way market," he said.
The Singapore dollar weakened further on continued dollar buying by U.S. funds, dealers said.
The local currency briefly tested 1.4385 before firming to 1.4372/82 at 0400 GMT.
"It's moving in tandem with dollar/yen," said a dealer with a local bank. He added he did not expect further firmness in dollar/Sing unless dollar/yen rises sharply.
Elsewhere, the Taiwan dollar remained weak but recovered from an eight-year low against the greenback after the central bank emerged to fend off speculation.
After hitting a low of 27.935 to the dollar, the Taiwan dollar was seen trading at 27.912/915 to the dollar at 0400 GMT. It was expected to range between 27.90-94 on Tuesday.

The Philippines peso stablised after recent hectic trade following Thailand's move to a managed float exchange rate system. The peso traded within a tight range of 26.383/385 in the morning. There was no evidence of intervention by the central bank on Tuesday.
-- Syed Azman in Kuala Lumpur (603-206 2323), Mantik Kusjanto in Jakarta (6221 384-6364), Anuchit Nguyen in Bangkok (662) 652-0642 and Angela Tan in Singapore (65-8703090)
